title: Bilateral Otosclerosis with Mixed Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I've had hearing loss in both ears for several years, along with ringing. My hearing aid in my left ear is ten years old and keeps cutting in and out.

problem_summary.course: Chronic; patient has worn a hearing aid for 10 years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus; history of noise exposure (hunting).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Current ITC hearing aid (left ear) is intermittent and has an omnidirectional microphone.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking management for hearing loss and replacement/upgrade of malfunctioning device.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral hearing loss due to otosclerosis. She experiences bilateral tinnitus.
history.otologic_history: History of otosurgery in the left ear. No other otologic symptoms reported.
history.noise_exposure_history: History of noise exposure from hunting.
history.medical_psych_history: Family history of hearing loss (father and grandfather).
history.prior_management: Has worn a Left ITC hearing aid for 10 years (omnidirectional mic, currently intermittent).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Severe mixed hearing loss (250-1000 Hz), rising to moderately severe at 2000 Hz, sloping to severe at 3000-4000 Hz. Left ear: Mild to moderately severe mixed hearing loss (250-3000 Hz), rising to moderate at 4000 Hz, sloping to severe at 6000-8000 Hz. Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

numeric_results.Left BC Masking: Could not mask for left BC at 250, 1k, 3k, 4k Hz due to magnitude of HL and ABG in right ear

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) show slight difficulty in the right ear and normal ability in the left ear at elevated presentation levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured due to the previous otosurgery.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral mixed hearing loss consistent with her history of otosclerosis. The right ear exhibits a severe degree of loss, while the left ear (previous surgery) shows a mild to moderately severe degree. Despite the mixed nature and severity of the loss, word recognition ability remains good in both ears when speech is amplified sufficiently.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms mixed hearing loss in both ears, likely related to the otosclerosis and family history you described.
Because of your previous ear surgery, we did not perform pressure tests today.

We recommend a trial with new hearing aids before considering any further surgery. Binaural (two) BTE (Behind-The-Ear) hearing aids would provide significant benefit over your single, intermittent in-the-canal aid.
It is important to use hearing protection when hunting to prevent further noise-induced damage.
We recommend annual hearing tests to monitor your hearing levels.
notes_for_actor: You have a history of hunting, which is a specific detail regarding your noise exposure.
You are likely frustrated that your current hearing aid (left ear) is 10 years old and not working reliably.
You have a strong family history of hearing loss (father and grandfather).
